docs.lead_paragraph: Q. Is there a way to beat the high cost of insurance on car rentals? A. Vacationing in France last summer, I drove my rented Audi into a pillar in an indoor parking garage, amputating the side-view mirror and putting a sharp crease in the front fender. As unnerved as I was by the accident, I was also pleased, because it meant I'd be getting a tangible payoff from the exorbitantly priced $20-a-day collision damage waiver I'd bought.

headline.main: Rental Car Insurance: Staying Out of Financial Potholes

docs.abstract: Minding Your Business column answers question about ways to beat high cost of insurance on car rentals; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Government researchers are recommending that thousands of people exposed to radiation leaked from a Washington State site 50 years ago be monitored for possible thyroid problems. About 14,000 people whose thyroids received significant doses of radiation from releases of material by the Hanford Nuclear Reservation, near Richland in southern Washington, from 1945 to 1951 should be found and offered regular medical evaluations, the researchers said on Thursday.

headline.main: Exams Urged for Neighbors Of 1945-51 Atomic Leaks

docs.abstract: Government researchers recommend that thousands of people exposed to radiation leaked from Hanford Nuclear Reservation in Washington State 50 years ago be monitored for possible thyroid cancers and other radiation-related conditions affecting the gland; say there are about 14,000 people whose thyroids received significant doses of radiation from these releases (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-7 Agreement to Disagree Ends Helsinki Summit President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin ended a two-day summit meeting in Helsinki by agreeing to differ over NATO expansion. They decided that Russia would negotiate a partnership agreement of its own that would be signed before NATO begins adding new members. They also reached agreements on arms-control issues that will require legislative approval. 1 Blast Kills 4 in Tel Aviv A blast touched off by a suicide bomber ripped through a crowded Tel Aviv cafe, killing the bomber and three others, injuring dozens and doing further damage to the Israeli-Palestinian peace effort. No group formally claimed responsibility for the attack, but unconfirmed reports suggested the bomber was a Palestinian from near Hebron, and an anonymous caller told the police that the militant Islamic movement Hamas was behind the attack. 1
